Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: The launch date was moved up and architects from multiple teams are blocked until they provide decisions
Story: I was hunched over my laptop, fingers flying across the keyboard as Slack notifications pinged relentlessly. The architects from three different teams were waiting on my input to finalize the API design, and the product manager had just announced the launch date was moved up—again. My mind was racing, trying to juggle the technical details and the pressure of not holding everyone else up. Just then, my phone buzzed. It was Sam, an old acquaintance from college, asking if I could recommend a good restaurant nearby for his anniversary dinner. He sounded genuinely excited, and I knew he trusted my taste. I felt a pang of guilt—he was counting on me for a quick, thoughtful answer, but my mind was tangled in code and deadlines. I stared at the message, torn between the urge to help Sam and the knowledge that every minute I spent away from my work would delay the entire project. My heart thudded as I weighed the expectations: be a supportive friend, or a reliable teammate.
